Many constituents have expressed legitimate concerns about how their right to bear arms will be treated by the incoming Gen. Assembly and I share their concerns. For my part as a Congressman I will continue to stand up for this God-given right acknowledged in the 2nd Amendment.

The right to keep and bear arms is a foundational freedom of our country. In fact Virginia demanded a bill of rights as a condition of ratifying the Constitution. Throughout my time in public service I have been a strong supporter of the Second Amendment.

Today we again honor the victims and the heroes of September 11 2001. This morning I participated in a moment of silence in memory of all who lost their lives on this day eighteen years ago. https://t.co/bF6tn0gRBO

The first responders who ran into burning buildings the Flight 93 passengers who took back the plane aimed at the Capitol all who risked and in many cases gave their lives to save others on 9/11 will be remembered as long as our country endures.

Like most Americans I could not fathom the hatred and cruelty that would lead anybody to kill almost 3000 innocent people in such a horrifying manner. But just as we will not forget the evil of that day we will always remember the heroism.
Americans will never forget the evil committed by terrorists in New York Virginia and Pennsylvania on September 11 2001. I still remember the disbelief I felt when watching the attacks.

If we are truly to remember the lessons of the Holocaust we must recommit now to ending the hate of anti-Semitism.

Horrific shootings at synagogues have targeted people gathered to worship. They were perpetrated by individuals with fringe ideas but anti-Semitism was also recently seen in a cartoon published by one of the country’s foremost newspapers.

On this Holocaust Remembrance Day #WeRemember the six million Jewish and other victims of Nazi tyranny. Although Hitler’s regime has been consigned to an ignominious place in history recent events have shown that anti-Semitism still lingers.
